>>efdf8c96-db7e-4835-afda-23925f1f0860
Just setup zeronet on a laptop anew. 
Zeroid is a real bitch with the default Tor-Browser. You have to disable NoSCript, since it breaks the ZeroID fetch.
Same with umatrix and ublock Origin. You have to disable them, or ZeroID just fails with a shitty mysterious error.
I bet this alone cost quite a bunch of users.

>Or would the total loss of that market and cessation of all trade be acceptable to you?
Seeing how most electronics goes through the asian market, china could fuck us really good in a technological capacity.
Block resources going towards motherboard  or CPU production and suddenly technological progress halts in western countries. 
Jonathan Blow did a great talk on this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pW-SOdj4Kkk [ Preventing the Collapse of Civilization ]
One of his points was how modern programming and computing in general has lost it's basic understanding of how computers work and we have become dependent on others for our technological needs. Also how modern computing has not made programmers more productive, in fact the opposite occurred. (32:30 onward)

You may have noticed how even Captcha is currently disabled on there :^)

>>4dbf6440-5412-43f2-9d03-5bf2643479eb
>>d98b603e-0df5-49a0-8a12-aeeb85fafc23
>Is "good opsec" thing some Qtard meme
It's not a meme. It's the practice of limiting or completely preventing leaks of critical information that can used by an adversary against you.
"Good opsec" is knowing upfront what information it is that you want to protect and taking reasonable steps in ensuring that it stays only with you.
In the context of anons that critical information is identity. I got bitten by hefty fine for torrenting because I failed to ensure my identity was not revealed. In a different setting it's different information. In a military conflict you know the identity of your opponent, but maybe not his position. So good opsec in that context is ensuring your position is not revealed.
>If Tor and even VPNs are banned on there
With TOR you can always use bridges if a ban is in effect. If the outgoing direction is banned or if you are the only one in a network to be using tor you can always just SSH into another machine or a VPS. This prevents the "associations attacks" (like that university student book uploader who got caught, even though he did it through TOR, he was found because only a single connection on the campus was using TOR at the moment of the crime - his). And if you truly must ensure privacy at all cost, like living in a state that actively hunts you (eg. journalists in china), you can always rent a VPS with bitcoin, SSH into it and use TOR form the VPS. No banlist on earth can ban that and no reasonable method known can trace you back.
>then what would be "bad opsec"?
But all of that for an anon would be "bad opsec". Because the whole mark of good opsec is "taking reasonable steps". Paranoia is not reasonable. It the same old classics: don't use private information, don't resuse nicks, never use you private E-Mail for shitty stuff. pic related. So now I'm one of those assholes, who torrents through TOR. (Although I also dedicate 25mbit of traffic to a TOR node to repent...)
All the great busts of hackers and drug dealers are never because of technology, it's always the shitty classics like paying with your credit card for illegal stuff or revealing your name. It's always that which fails. For that angle there is the bust of silk road for more info: https://darknetdiaries.com/episode/24/
tl;dr: Don't be paranoid and don't be a moron

>>8f3a9f94-8399-419c-b750-1d2e8a2f49fc
>They're not going to give the legacy boards to just anyone
The topic of mods on image boards is always a conflict. That's actually good. With so many out to get 8kun, I wouldn't want /v/, /tech/ or /pol/ to land in hands of reddit vigilante larpers.
>rules are going to be carefully crafted to allow for as little freedom as possible
Bullshit. I don't recall any point in time where the rules on 8chan prevented you from anything except CP. Power tripping mods were never more than a week long incident and 4chan was the one to ban topics like GG out of political fear. 8chan was taken down specifically *because* it did not have that fear. The rules will stays as they always are. No CP with instant bans for violation. If cm fails in leading 8chan it will not be because of that.
>Problem posters will be shadow banned
How on earth would you shadow ban on an image  board? This would never fly. Shadow banning does not work in the context of an image board.

>>fb46f435-c49f-4b1b-9c4f-e5c49be71e6a
By Zeronet server you may mean the *server* part as in hosting websites on zeronet...
>how resistant a Zeronet server
Many services on Zeronet are setup decentralized. There is no server to begin with, nothing you can take down.

By Zeronet server you may also mean the program you launch to access zeronet, which is what I gather from your post. (in that context it's not a server)
>much it protects the Tor browser from compromise
Zeronet is completely independent from a browser. Your browser never connects to the internet. The reason that the TOR browser is recommended is for ease of setup of tor itself and if you use the same browser for clearnet and darknet, so that those things don't get conflated and that no privacy trackers or telemtry see darknet activity.
You can go to your firewall, completely block the browser from ever accessing the internet and zeronet still works.
>would be a much harder app than the Tor browser
The Zeronet client uses a forked version of the bit torrent protocol. The attack surface for stuff like remote code execution is vastly smaller, since Zeronet is "just a glorified torrent program". There is no javascript to hijack, no SQL database to check for missing quotation marks. Itself zeronet suffers from the same thing bit torrent suffers from. Zero privacy if you don't have any proxy, since everyone sees your IP. It depends on TOR for that.

> And why do those missing trackers return after Zeronet restart?
I have seen this as well and would be interested as well. A question for the #zeronet IRC I suppose

>>f191add2-0135-464f-898c-b4c4fdcb9089
>Why the fuck should I hide?
It's not about hiding. It's about principles.
umatrix the shit out of every website, not because of some vague sense of privacy, but because Alphabet and facebook have no deal making money with data about you.
Your identity is not their income.
Hide your IP and your Nicks when expressing yourself, not because of what you have to say will never warrant anything coming your way, as you're an uninteresting noise in the sea of opinions, but because the government should not even get a chance to dictate what wrong think is.
England's police has an internet hate speech division, germany took people away in handcuffs for facebook posts and new zealand launched an autism level of speech policing.
None of this will probably ever hit you. 
It's not because you are probably safe doing what you do, but to prove to the world it can be different.
Out of principle.

>>3814b682-d3f7-4a9e-aa40-155c9388609e
I torrent exclusively through TOR. Vidya, movies, you name it.
That blog post is carefully worded misinformation at best and lying at worst. If their post was even close to the truth, VPNs could not work either with bt. Of course the TOR devs don't want bt traffic on their network, but their shitty stance on this by releasing bad info has been criticized for years.
==Let's just quickly debunk that smut==
>First attack "popular Bittorrent clients just ignore their socks proxy setting in this case
Maybe this used to be a bug in the past, but every torrent application has specifically a setting to only use the proxy exclusively. See pic 1, checkmark 2.
>simply write your IP address directly into the information they send to the tracker and/or to other peer
If that was true, a VPN could not save you either. No anonymous bit torrent could even exist. But of couse that's bullshit. This is how PeX worked in the past. It should be disabled by default and if not, there is a checkmark for it with a tooltip saying use this shit if you use a VPN.
>The second attack builds on the first one
And is completly non-sense. If that was true, vpns would not help either. This is only the case, if you specifically tell the torrent application to use the proxy for trackers but not for peers. See pic1 checkmark 1. It's always enabled by default to not have this happen.
>As a bonus, if the Bittorrent peer communications aren't encrypted
You wot cunt?! Encryption was always there since the invention of the bt protocol, at least in the spec. You can tell any bt application, even the most shitty one to reject all non encryption connection, just like you can only use https instead of http. But even if this was the case, this would not be bad. Everybody knows the content, it's p2p after all morons, we just hide the destination. Not the content needs protection, it's our identity. 
>exit relays can build short snapshots of user profiles based on all the streams
This is the most asinine one, the most ass backwards context free argument. The same if true for regular browsing too. If you watch a video over tor, the same is true. It's part of the so called "association attack" and no content is free from that. Besides that you would need a nation state actor to do so, all of TOR is >theoretically vulnerable to this.
>>f385b4a0-c51b-4c6f-b728-7b174cd31e7e
So yeah. Tor has a problem with bt due to traffic constriction. That is ok. Their misinformation is not.
I run a tor node to so china journalist will still have a good connection, whilst I'm torrenting hentai.

>>606fcc2b-6c42-4213-99e0-fcb7dde7ff11

Make yourself comfy and ask away.

Zeronet banks on mass adoption, that's when p2p truly plays to it's strength. And the rest of tech will not just roll over and give it to us.

>>e74b85e3-8052-41ad-a21e-2c5d62ade4e0
The distinction really starts to break down, doesn't it? Is it still torrenting, when the bt protocol is used to serve websites? Under the hood there is barely any difference between a bit torrent client and zeronet, but the context is certainly different. In the end, whether it's 3MB of website content going through bit torrent or over https is of no difference. It's 3MB of bandwidth on the shoulders of TOR either way.
>>b3ba25ab-fad5-4ef3-a185-82177168cb0e
And yet we are all here. In the decentralized deep net. Journalists have targeted this website and leaked IPs not under a proxy. It's not about whether SWAT is about to bust down your front door. It's about the principle of not giving an inch.
Depending on where you live, it's as close to reality as it gets, especially with Germany arresting people over "right wing" facebook posts. Why tempt fate by showing of your powerlevel to the state?

>>68652f77-101a-45b7-a964-2d018d6d3c3b
reddit formatting has been around before reddit was a thing. I don't like it either, but structuring your post into paragraphs has been a thing on chans before.
>>46262ba4-c218-48e1-95b1-110387dd2c3e
>much less attack surface than Tor browsing
That's certainly true. Ultimately, nothing stops the board owner form putting a piece of javascript in place, that leaks info about your browser to some server. But this is beaten by the simple fact, that you can block your browser from connecting to the internet and you are safe from those types of attack.
>Might make any Zeronet node on Tor truly hard to find
Zeronet does not have any de-anonymizing features in itself. As long as you trust the proxy, Zeronet is bulletproof. Any anonymizing attack that can be used against TOR users, can be used against Zeronet users, as long as you use TOR as your Zeronet proxy. Association attacks, Timing attacks are all still technically viable, although much harder to pull off with the p2p angle. But unless the circumstances are perfect (being the only tor user on a campus network) you are pretty much bulletproof, as long as TOR remains bulletproof. With the US military relying on TOR, this is not gonna change any time soon.

>>444253e6-0dbd-426f-bc6f-86954a96c51e
There are a bunch of us lovely gentlemen spreading our seed into the void - 24/7
Should be done in no time (・`ω´・)

>>39a0bcee-1b6f-4c39-bba3-c5c407653afd
>Tor Browser (or firefox) still exposed and lots of options for de-anonymizing attacks.
==What the fuck are you smoking.==
You can Remove the LAN cable. Shut off your router. Queue a post on 08chan, completely uninstall all browsers, and then reconnect the cable to have the post propagate. The browser is of no consequence and isn't even really involved with zeronet in the first place.
>your node has a tor endpoint but you publish your own content until it gets mirrored
>t's probably trivially to match them technically
Anon just stop. Even a minute on the tor wiki page contradicts your bullshit.
In the TOR browser or without the browser via nyx, you can refresh you identity, circuit and endpoint every 60 seconds and every single post you make. The cert we post under identifies our content, but changing the cert and refreshing the identity completely breaks any piece of information that can be grouped. Of course you can be a dumb cunt and identify yourself ==by the content== of your posts, but that is just what a post is.
>>fb8cac14-39e5-4921-9ba5-387204330cc9
The javascript without a browser is of no consequence. If it was anything else it wouldn't change the dynamic. If there is a privacy leak it will be there, be it javascript or not. The language here stops being a factor, because no browser is actually involved anymore. No scripts embedded within html that can leak your info. Ultimately this this can still be the case if you use the browser to access your local content, but you can just firewall it off and that danger is taken care of. How the structuring within Zeronet is done doesn't matter from that angle. It may be done with java or racket, the dynamic stays the same.
>>accdfa93-12d2-42f9-a0b4-7ae00c3993f0
I urge you to open the task manager or htop, w/e you are on. Zeronet is single threaded. It cannot and does not demand more than a single core from you. I'm seeding 5 zites, with "Download and distribute all files" enabled and the full history downloaded. The directory is 80GB. My RAM usage for Zeronet is 182MB, even though the last restart is over a day past.
Sure it pins that one core to 100% when posting or opening up a new site to serve content to the browser, but I think the whole resource angle is overstated. pic related. 43MB for tor, 182MB for Zeronet. Sure the browser is a 300MB hog, but that's today's bowsers anyhow...

>>a4591511-edf7-45a0-8ce9-4e44847d419a
>like fapping once a week
>at least no suicidal thoughts
>even my mouth odor vanished
>the year before the flu didn't leave m
This is on the level of going blind from touching your peepee.
They should hand out flyers...
>Do you touch your dick at least once a week?
>Did you know that's the reason for your weak immune system, bad breath and depression?

>>74f66df9-3060-471d-9f71-1f40b2670a7b
>External harddrive enclosure
>sold by a retailer
You can be sure, that those are the lowest of low tier.
>Are they SMR drives?
Enclosures are privy to a trick. They list the product number of the ==enclosure== (WDBCKA0120HBK-NESN). You don't know what actual ==hard drive== you will get. So really, there is no way to say. You can search on the internet for that model number and the word "shucked". You will find people removing the shell and posting what harddrive they found in. Then you know what you are getting. Without a doubt those are cheap in the TB per $ department. But if you actually care about your data, you will get yourself any external enclosure yourself and then ==you== decide what is put in them.

>>3f2b36e4-cea0-4f9e-b37f-ebfec6b2dcfb
Lovely. If you can, scan it in, so I can lose my mind over the internet once again...

>>ee553923-1491-4729-af8e-75f837f7a566
>may not matter
True, it all depends on what you consider an acceptable level of risk. Although error correction cannot and is not done on the hardware side. (Talking bit-rot here, not read/write verification) That's the filesystem's job. And NTFS has been a real cunt with that.
>"fooled by randomness"
Without a doubt that's most of opinions on the internet. The sample size of one customer's experience is usually insignificant. Luckily many great firms with tech, not corporate at their heart release a crap ton of info about it.
Backblaze being one. 4 times a year they release stats and lifespan on every had drive bought, installed and replaced. This is the current:
https://www.backblaze.com/blog/backblaze-hard-drive-stats-q3-2019/
So digging up info like this is always my first stop before going into an upgrade cycle for any rack.
